description:
I have a weird thing for dive bars. I really enjoyed this place. It is literally across the street from my hotel and so my wife decided to stop in on Saturday night. It's just a small bar that has walls covered in crap and two big T.V.s playing sports. The wife and I sat at the end of the bar and had quite a few beers and whiskey and the bartenders were very friendly. I saw that they had some peanuts behind the bar and they gave me a serving of peanuts to enjoy with my beers. 

When we first got there there were not many people but all of a sudden about 20 extra people filled into the bar. The bar plays loud music that seemed to be controlled by a jukebox that you pay for. Everybody seemed to be having a good time in there and everybody was friendly who came in. I also like how they chill the glasses for the beer; it's not something I would've expected from a dive bar! The prices were okay for a bar. The beer was $5 which is good but the well whiskey was pretty pricey for what it was. It's a very cool place and I will be back.
author: Nico M.

description:
When I review any spot, whether a restaurant or a bar, I mentally start from 5 stars and deduct from there. Therefore this place gets 4 stars because it's dark, graffiti-covered and charming (good things for a dive bar) yet the Minimum card fee
(The sign says credit card though it applies to debit too - Not good) is $20 Freaking dollars. One whole star deducted for that. Otherwise this place is worthy of the movies - a perfect dive bar with very very warm funny staff and clientele.
author: Willie M.

description:
John (owner of the Shelton theatre) brought a group of us here after one of his shows last weekend and we all had such an amazing time! 

The 2 ladies behind the bar made us all feel welcomed - took shots with us and even let me and the girls behind the bar to play around with their antique cash register. They probably thought we were being weirdos but we were super intrigued. 

Drinks were reasonably priced and they sure do have a heavy hand when it comes to mixed drinks/cocktails - no complaints here! 

This was our last stop and last night in SF so we hung out for a couple hours. Chatting with our new friends and made some great memories, glad that Chelsea Place was a part of our trip. Cannot wait to come back & visit again. :)
author: Julie R.

description: SERIOUSLY, YOU CAN DO BETTER. I know it's a shady part of town and one dive bar looks like another, but this place is possibly the worst in the Tenderloin. Unless of course you are a fan of mystery prices (my first well whiskey and Diet Coke was $8, already not great. My second WELL whiskey and Diet Coke was $10. Cool.) and shrill bartenders (I know people can't completely control their own voice, but sweet shouting jesus were these bartenders loud, high pitched, and obnoxious). High Tide, Cinnibar, and Nite Cap are all faaaarrrrrr better options.
author: Tom J.

description: I randomly wandered into this place. I was surprised to see Asian bartenders but hey it's all good made me feel more comfortable ? Jk lol laidback environment good customer service and the prices for drinks were not bad. My usual shot of henny and a Heineken
author: Jin K.

description:
I was walking with my co-worker, one drink in and we were looking to find a chill dive bar with some locals and regulars to have a post work day cheap beer. He remembered Chelsea Place, where he had been a couple times and had some fun moments. 
Just outside of Chinatown this is a fun little dive bar with some uniques characteristics! 
The first memorable one would be the little dog in a dog pillow behind the bar! Who would pop his head up from his golden slumber every few minutes. 
There were some tourist guys flirting with bartenders, and what looked like a regular who had been there for 15 hours, sitting watching the ball game eating some of the free peanuts, we were offered as well. 

Beers were cheap, and hit the spot! 
The bathroom is an adventure in it's own right, down the narrow stairs and through a narrow hall way... Definitely not handicap accessible.. But you are greeted by a hilarious poster of Mick Jagger, so I did enjoy that! 

All in all fun, no frills, bar with a sleeping dog.. and free peanuts.. I dig it!
author: Patrick T.

description:
We went to SF to try and find someplace to watch the super bowl, we had other places in mind but after other places being WAY too crowded we ended up here. 

First thing I noticed was it was very tiny and a little hole in the wall place. I was skeptical but we were greeted so nice by every single bartender and even customers! 

There was a lot of people there and everyone still made room for us to sit and made sure we were ok and if we needed water or wanted a drink. It was like they were a big family. 

Staff was awesome! The girls were screaming and yelling playing games with the customers and just having the best time! 

There was free food they had provided and it was open to anyone. Drinks were a decent price and served really good (good pours!) 

Only thing was the bathroom was very dirty and as a woman I HATE a dirty bathroom. 

Other than that I would definitely come back here!
author: Adriana B.

description: The bartender on duty in any bar sets the mood of the venue.  At this bar, one regular bartender makes this place unwelcoming by way of being judgmental and not understanding the clientele.  It's a dive bar that should be cool by way of location, but is uncomfortable when this person is working.  SF has a hundred more places worth spending time and money on.  This one, don't bother.
author: Vince C.

description: This was the best part of my SF trip this Feb. The bartender was incredible!! She taught me a dice game that was really fun and took a shot with me! The patrons were friendly and one even had great recommendations for a trip I'm planning on taking in May. Please do not pass up this place, it's amazing. They also have free popcorn and peanuts for customers. You'll love this divey bar.
author: Sidney G.

description: Either the drinks here are way more expensive than the place would lead you to believe or my friends were ordering some kind of insanely top shelf nonsense, and a lot of it. After an hour and a half our tab was $80! Cute dark spot but there are others in the area with cheaper drinks, pool tables, and other attractions. They do have free pretzels though so maybe that's what you're paying for!
author: Kaia V.

description: A guy asked the bar tender if the prices were correct, considering how high they are. The bar tender straight up took his debit card, bent it in half trying to break it and threw it on the dance floor. ALSO, if someone's significant other or family member asks a bar tender to stop serving their partner, they are required to stop. That is the law. A couple Bar tenders here are out of control in a NOT so dive-bar-fun way. The audacity...
author: Sam W.

description:
Friendly staff and you can even get sake here. You get free popcorn and I believe there's jukebox (or something of the sort) in the back that a friend used for music selection. A friend recommended the place so we stopped by here on the way back as we were wrapping up Santacon.

You can play dice w/ the bartender and winner gets a free drink. Haha be careful winning too fast. In the end, the bartender always wins.
author: James N.

description: Horrible service! Drinks were under poured and I was asked to pay before I even tried my drink. Was planning on hanging out for a bit but not after being forced to pay before I even had a sip. Will not go back and I do not recommend this place.
author: TSwizzle 3.

description:
The Good.

Free popcorn.
Cheap(ish) drinks.
Champagne flutes for cheap beer.

The Bad.

Being called "Gen-Y Cunts" by the regulars.
Using bathrooms that feel as though you could be murdered at any moment.
The vulgarity of serving anything other than the Champagne of Beers in champagne flutes.

The Ugly.

Actually BEING "Gen-Y Cunts." Truth hurts.
author: Peter D.

description: Great bar, PBR cans!  Feels like a down home WV bar in San Francisco! Juke box was great also. Not a huge selection of beers but not needed!  Great people also.
author: Nick E.

description: Awesome neighborhood dive. Don't listen to the negative reviews - they are hipsters or out of towners. Cheap beer free snacks nice bartenders
author: Chris B.

description: Have you ever spent $50 on a shitty drink?!  If you're into a very shitty drink come here. They're bar tenders are liars and full of sh*t, charging triple on an open tab. Absolutely the worst
author: Galina A.

description: If you want to listen to awful music, this is the place. Drop a fiver in the jukebox, play awesome music, have the staff override it with awful top 40 or techno.
author: David K.

description: Came here cause it was across the street from my hotel on my birthday. Got a free shot and the girls sang me happy birthday! All drinks were reasonably priced and we had a bunch of fun!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
I like a good dive bar as much as the next guy, but this place is just gross. While I've never had dysentery, this visit to Chelsea Place was probably the greatest exposure to the disorder that I've ever had.

My wife returned from a trip to the ladies room saying that she felt like she was in some sort of bad horror movie, and someone wearing a hockey mask would be springing in at any moment. Unfortunately, I had to go myself, and I am not happy to report that the smell in the mens room was such that I came very, very close to throwing up. Mind you, this was not the smell of one person who failed to perform a "courtesy flush" -- this was the smell of decades-old rotting flesh.

I expected that with a place that smelled and looked like this, well drinks would have been practically free -- instead, the opposite was true, and I found them to be quite overpriced.

I need to take a shower just thinking about this place.
author: Jim C.

description:
PBR tastes better when consumed out of Champagne glasses. In fact, everything tastes better champers-style. But here at Chelsea Place, said luxuries are restricted to two patrons at a time. That's the sum total number of Champagne glasses they have on site. But they'll readily provide them to you if you ask. 

Because really, everything is better when sipped from a flute. Even in a filthy dive with sketchy ass bathrooms. 

My first visit here was pretty bad. We were called "Gen-Y Cunts" by some jerk who hates the world. My second visit here was polar opposite. Friendly welcoming service, and regulars who left us alone. 

Not much more you could ask from a seedy dive atop a tunnel in the middle of The City.
author: Don B.

description: Best bartenders in the world. Ask to play the dice game and win some free shots if you win
author: Ryan O.

description: This place is the actual worst. The women behind the bar are rude, the regulars are rude, and the overall atmosphere is deplorable. I have never hated a bar more (and I've been to a lot of bars). Would highly recommend going literally anywhere else.
author: Janine D.

description:
Duck tape patching up a hole in the sink and a garbage can just out sitting out in the open pretty much sum this place up. If it were a truck it'd definitely be of the dump variety. They do have free popcorn but if you eat it you're much braver than I. 

As you could imagine the people watching is top notch. There's some surly sketchballs so participate with caution, but it can definitely be an entertaining spot to spend a drink or two.
author: Danny W.

description:
Not all dives are created equal, and this dive is certainly inneresting. 

PBR served in Champagne flutes, complimentary burnt popcorn, Maruchan Ramen for the drunkards that need to sober up. And the drinks? They're served in tiny tumblers, but they're stiff. In all, I like!

The ladies restroom is surprisingly clean. - albeit it's a skurry trek into the basement.
author: Farrah A.

description:
Yes, the bathrooms are kind of gross and it may have an odd scent but it is a dive bar. The one star is based on horrible service. 

Had an extremely poor experience with staff, overall rude and unfriendly vibes. It was obvious we weren't regulars and were treated as such from the bartenders and initially by some of the other customers. 

My first concern was that I was not provided with change when I paid in cash and it's a $20 limit via card (I gave $12 for a $7 shot, I let it go because my group was sitting there a bit before I ordered a drink and I felt bad/decided that the $5 would be my tip for the night). 

Secondly, a friend (who is obviously not from the U.S.) ordered a red bull and vodka with the assumption that we would get a red bull can and a vodka shot. When he tried to explain what he wanted, the bartender became unnecessarily aggressive. Instead of allowing us to just buy an extra red bull in peace (which we asked immediately after she told us that's not how they serve the drink), the bartender had the nerve to lecture and argue with us about how she doesn't give things out for free and that redbull is typically very expensive. 

The dice drink betting game is a unique characteristic of this bar, but I'm certainly never returning based on such rude service (which was a huge bummer because it had potential). I would not recommend coming here and regret providing any business for this place.
author: Alexis M.

description: Was in San Francisco for 3 nights and this is the only place we went to more than once. On the 2nd night the Bartender actually remembered my drinks from the night before and had them ready for me before we even sat down. Best Bartender Ever. The whole staff was very friendly and they interact with the customers. I will definitely return.
author: Ken G.

description: No dart board! It's a dive... The prices weren't as reasonable as advertised! Drinks were good, seemed like it was full of regulars.
author: Allison M.

description: It's true, this place really does have a faint smell of vomit. I'm sure it's just a matter of stale beer that's found it's way into crevices throughout the place but I would do something about it if I were the owner.  The people were nice, the prices are good.  I wouldn't go back nor would I recommend it to anyone unless you're looking to save money and don't mind the smell.
author: Altadena S.

description: This bar is a nice little spot on bush st. In SF - it's kinda divey but if you want a cool spot to grab a drink the patrons are nice and inviting. Next time I stay at my hotel here on Bush I am for sure headed back to this place.
author: Danny S.

description: The place reeked of vomit. Not sure if someone straight up yacked all over the place, or whether the bar itself is that dirty. The bartender's boyfriend showed up and they got into a fight. Could've used a beer while I watched the wrestling match. The stairs walking down and back up from the bathroom were something out of the movie the Shining. Thought I would fall through at any moment. But, hey... Its a dive bar. Go for it, I guess.
author: AJ L.

description: A good dive bar (wherever you are) is packed. Why? Because it's cheap. 3 drinks over $20. Not the greatest bartenders. The only plus is you get free snacks like popcorn. I'm a dive bar fan but not this one. Also, creepy bathrooms in the basement. There's other places you can go and spend the same amount.
author: Cara F.

description:
Well, it is what it is.  It's a dive bar.  As dive as it gets.
Not a long time ago they even allowed smoking there.  Run by Asians so there is always Chinese and Korean ladies working there. 
Drinks could be a bit cheaper for the dive bar.  Otherwise service is reasonable.
I'd come back once in a while.
author: Alex R.

description:
Pros: friendly, cute bartenders. Reasonable price

Cons: $20 minimum on credit car charge which is rare now day and very inconvenience.

Fine place for a drink before bed. A lot annoying mid age old man tried to impressed the bartender by being loud and stupid lol
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Kitschy dive that offers a nice reprive from the bespoke cocktail trend in the area.

Service is quick, prices are good for the area, and the bar is usually well-staffed to accomodate for large crowds. The crowd itself is an interesting mix of tourists, transplants exploring their surroundings, regulars, and crusty older folks who eye newbs with suspicion.

The place can get stuffy in warm weather , and it's a bit of a treacherous trip down the stairs to the restroom. It's worth the journey, though, because the wall graffiti features an on-going debate on which bartender is the hottest.

The bartenders will engage you with conversation, games (dice, Asian drinking games, etc.), and assertively rack you for more drinks. Don't take it for a hustle; it's just cultural--in various parts of Asia, bartenders perform double duty and provide entertainment as well. (Think: booze laden version of Benihana.)
author: Sam W.

description: Hmmm. I was bar hopping with the bf last Saturday and decided to give this place a try since the yelp reviews weren't so bad. Meh. It was a run down dive bar that played punk girl rock music (which) gave me a headache. So we only had one drink and left to another bar. I don't think I would come back.
author: Judy V.

description: Never going there again! A little expensive then your normal dive bar! Rude aggressive bartenders!
author: Jon M.

description: The ladies here know how to provide real service. They know us by name, know our drinks, play dice with us... Real hospitality!!!
author: Jess B.

description: Great dive bar with friendly staff and cold beer.  The regulars are amusing and add charm and character to this SF dive.  The staff/waitresses add the edge!  Stayed in SF for two nights and stopped by both times.  It is without a doubt a truly unique experience.  The boss was a fan as well!
author: Curtis K.

description: This place is a dive, but not in the good friendly cheers way, it's a dive in the "we're going to hustle you out of as much money as possible" way. Twenty dollar minimum and the bartenders are always hustling you to buy them "shots" at $10 each and egging you on.  This place exists to take advantage of tourists from the union square area and don't really treat the neighbors as family, they treat you like a ATM. Pretty disappointing
author: Michael R.

description: Great neighborhood joint with friendly locals! I think I'm in love. I highly recommend checking this place out.
author: Max C.

description:
Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name.... Like Norm and Cliff and the rest of the gang, I understand the appeal of a dive bar where you don't have to impress anyone and where the regulars rule the roost. But sometimes dive bars have a dark side. 

I learned this the hard way when I wandered in to Chelsea Place with some coworkers on a weekday night looking for a casual place to have a beer. There were some sketchy looking characters smoking at the bar (yes, you heard that right folks, smoking cigarettes) who gave us wary glances as we made our way to a table at the back of the bar. 

The bar's saving grace was a nice cocktail waitress who didn't have a problem with us hanging out and slowly sipping our beers. She even stopped and chatted with us a bit and told us a little about herself. I think some of my male coworkers may have developed a crush. 

The highlight of my night - and maybe my whole life - was when one of the grizzled regulars started berating one of my innocent friends for having his chair stick out too far into his path to the bathroom. Instead of a simple 'excuse me,' he chose to call us a word which I try not to say or even type as it's so offensive. Let's just say I'll see you next Tuesday. We were so shocked that we soon made our way to leave the bar, at which point the gentleman began to yell at us and call us awful names again, with the rest of the scary old regulars looking on dopily and the bartenders doing nothing about it. 

Sure, your regulars are valuable, but if you allow them to verbally abuse potential new customers, once they expire you'll have no new business... just a suggestion that you may want to be nice to everyone who walks in your door.
author: Christina P.

description:
Chelsea Place won't be giving Rye or Bourbon & Branch a run for their money anytime soon, but when you really want to throw a wrench into your typical Friday night plans, you really can't go wrong with a hang at Chelsea Place.

With a lead in like that, you'd expect something better than an "A-OK," right? Well, there are good reasons for that, my friend.

When I say "you really can't go wrong," it's because, like a box of chocolates, you never know what you're going to get. On any given night, it's very likely you'll have a long-winded conversation with a Korean War veteran, you'll be picked up on by exotic women with money on the mind, you may get into near bar brawls instigated by regular bar flies, and it's quite possible you'll exit with a strange itch or a newfound rash that wasn't present before arrival. It's a crap shoot, but by-and-large, you'll always leave with a tall tale to share with your future grandchildren.

They're one of the few bars that still let you smoke cigarettes inside, and if you have an extra Hamilton, the friendly, attractive bartenders will sit at your table and laugh at everything that comes out of your mouth.
author: Ruggy J.

description: OK so I ended up here again and have to say Chelsea Place seems to get more charming with each visit. That added star is for chatting up a guy about our favorite 90s college rock jams. Could've stayed there all night swapping tunes on the juke box. I mean, who likes to drink alone?
author: Will S.

description: Chill dive bar. I'm up in SF quite often and I'll be definitely be stoping by again. Thanks for the cheap PBR!!!
author: Bobby C.

description: It took me a couple of times to warm up to this place.  The beer is cheap and the bartenders are nice.  You go there a few times and you get to know the bartenders and the customers.  It is definitely for regulars but tourists are welcome as well.  The beer is very cheap and good.  For a dive bar they have cute bartenders!  Not like the dive bars in my part of Phoenix!
author: Mark H.

description: Always hit this place when I'm in town. Discovered it in 2008 when I heard Achille's Last Stand blasting from the jukebox and saw a couple of very cute Asian bartenders rocking to it as I walked by at 2pm ! Great drinking place with a wide variety of locals. The staff give off the vibe that they are just winging it and are there to party as well. Tres cool.
author: David D.

description: Bought 5 beers, played a game with bartenders and lost 4 times, which is 40$ for the bill. Payed 111$, feels too much.
author: Vadim g.

description:
A friend came up to SF for work and wanted to catch up. And who doesn't like catching up with a few beers?

Looking for a open bar before 5pm is a hard feat (most places open after 5), luckily we found Chelsea's Place. If we weren't already looking for Tunnel Top, we could have easily missed this place. 

Honestly, CP looked kind of sketch. We walked in, and within two seconds were on our way out. The bartender responded with something like "nooo, come back", and we did! She was adorable. 

Seating was very limited. There was a bar, and a few seats here and there. There's only one semi large table that fits about 4-5 comfortably. The place was also very dark. My two girlfriends and I ordered beers and sat at their largest table. 

The atmosphere was definitely more chill than other bars, there were a few people smoking and having light conversations. With us included (3), there were probably only 6 people there total. I felt kind of bad because it seemed like we were being loud--someone had to ask the bartender to raise the television volume up (woops).

Overall, not bad of a place to chill. Definitely seems like a place only regulars go to. If you cannot handle people smoking (like one of my friends), this isn't the place for you. On a good note, the owner (i'm assuming) was very sweet! Within 30 minutes of sitting down, she came and offered us a basket of pretzel sticks. Such a sweet gesture! 

They also have a happy hour! $2.50 for a bottle of beer, and $6-$8 for a beer and a shot.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I came here on 12/11 to grab a night cap after catching the Book of Mormon with my special lady in San Francisco. She passed out before we could go out for a drink, so I took a walk, and came across a place that looked god-awful, and said, damn, I need to drink a beer there. I yelped it on my phone quick and read the same thing: it's a dive, but it's like a family of regulars. I dig places like that.

So I go in, and it's surprisingly laid back inside. There's only a few people at the bar, including a Filipino dude who was falling asleep in his own hands, clearly drunk. Oh well, harmless. 

There were the two bartenders, who I later identified as Michelle and Jenna. These two were AWESOME. I don't often get out to bars anymore, especially in San Francisco (as I'm from San Jose). Jenna taught me how to play bar dice (I know this sounds lame, but it kept us busy). These two were friendly, funny, and totally took care of me. 

I met a gentleman who kept playing classic rock, turned out to be a nice dude. We talked the Who for awhile. It was just a pleasant experience with nice people. 

4/5 stars because they had a very limited tap (almost all of which I don't consider "beer", the best of which being Sam Adams), but the Sam ran out after my first one. I had to drink bottled Sierra Nevada the rest of the night. (I love Sierra, but ice cold Sam was tasting kind of good). 

Cheers to Michelle and Jenna. Thanks for the experience. I had a great time!
author: Scott B.

description: This place rocks, good beer, good bartenders, and you can control the music. Win.
author: Monika H.

description:
We aimed to go to Tunnel Top but is was closed so we came here.

"Dude this place looks shady as hell."
"Feck it, where's your sense of adventure?"

So we pushed the half door aside (you know the stable type door that a cow looks out over).

I guess it just felt so very classic San Francisco to me, very Dashiell Hammett style aka Maltese Falcon.

We sat at the bar and ordered our beer from the friendly Japanese server. To our left were men in military uniform and an old bar fly drinking miller high life. 

I guess that's why it was a four star experience for me, I do have a soft spot for bars that seem battered and sorrowful.
author: Annie L.

description: This was a decent dive bar, which was kind of surprising considering it is only blocks from Union Square. It has an annoying $20 minimum before you can use a credit card, and the clientele was very much skewed towards male travelers the night I was there. Still, the staff was very friendly and the price was right for a teacher on spring break in an expensive city.
author: Jud K.

description:
This place was ok.  The beers were pretty cheap.  I had them make me a round of mixed shots, I told them five and she made four and then just restrained them into five glasses when I corrected her.  I was still charged for five, which was pretty BS.  They play a dice game where if you win they buy you a drink, but when our group won they said it had to be 2 out of 3.  And, then when we won that, she said that we had to keep playing until it was even(?).  

So, they bought us a drink and we bought them a drink.  However, I'm fairly certain that the drink we bought them was water that they poured into a shot glass from a used Patron bottle(although we paid as if it was a patron shot). 

If not for the shenanigans with the dice game and the pouring four shots into five glasses, I would have rated this place a solid three star or maybe a four star.
author: Ted G.

description: Friendly staff, not super clean but the draft ale beer my husband and I got was great. Hip ambiance, dark lighting and a fun social hangout spot. Perfect spot to get a couple drinks before dinner.
author: Jewelz C.

description:
Looking for laid-back? 
Dive into this divey bar
Irish car bomb time
author: Jonathan C.

description: Bartenders were super friendly and I loved how there was free popcorn, pretzels, and peanuts! The crowd is a bit interesting but I guess it is a dive bar, though it should be described more as a classy dive bar.
author: Christina C.

description: My wife and I stop by here after a nice walk up and over Nob Hill and back.  The bartenders are avid sports fans, and the free popcorn can't be beat.  Good place for a beer and watching the end of Monday Night Football.
author: Joel S.

description:
This place is fun and Michelle takes care of the customers.Had a great time and met some cool people too.Opens early for you serious party animals that want to get your drink on early.
Drinks were GOOD !!!
author: Joe P.

description:
Exactly what the Doctor ordered... this place is a BAR.... call it a dive bar it is a simple, fun, uncomplicated and VERY friendly place. As stated before, the staff is fun, friendly and flirtatious but most of all, you'll get a drink served on time and as soon as you need it. The crowd is eclectic in a good way. It's not a young 20-something bar...  average age here was maybe 35 with a nice mix from 24-50... a cool mix of people and an awesome music selection. Friday night when I went it happened to be early 90's and some Smiths mixed in for good measure. If I lived here I could see myself just hanging at this place for a few beers on a regular basis. Great service too. 

No smoking indoors as far as I could see (Friday night 11:00pm)
author: Shane S.

description:
Not all the bartenders are Korean [ahem, *cough* Ruggy ;) *cough*] - at least two of them are Chinese.   However, they're all rather hot and genuinely friendly (to everybody, not just the dudes who go there for the eye candy), plus they're - surprise! - very good bartenders.  No need to worry about The Glare if you want something more complicated than a bourbon & coke - I've had very good manhattans, mai tais, and margaritas here, and the ladies (well, at least one of them) will do what they call a black margarita with chambourd.   I also saw many a kamikaze round prepared during a couple of the baseball games I watched here.

They serve up a variety of bar snacks if you ask - popcorn, peanuts, and I believe pretzels are an option too.  It is an occaisional smoking bar, generally in the later hours when a few drinks have been consumed, so beware if that's not your thing. 

Chelsea Place boasts 3 flat screen TVs and free wi-fi (no password required, very fast connection),  and is open at noon daily, unlike some bars (*cough* Tunnel Top *cough*) that aren't even open on Sundays, much less noon.  The only thing that bugs me is that the well bourbon & cokes are always at least $5, which would be just fine if they weren't served in teeny tiny minature collins glasses.  "Fancier" drinks (which are served in larger glasses) and call drinks tend to run $7-$10, and while credit cards are accepted, there's a $20 minimum.
author: Sus... B.

description: Absolutely love this place. The bartenders here care a lot about the customers and spend time to get to know them. I lovee the free popcorn.
author: Sahrenah S.

description: After a day of sight-seeing in San Francisco, we were looking for a few drinks before dinner. We Yelp'd closest dive bar & went to Chelsea Place. Super dark, sketchy & seedy characters....which was right up our alley. The place was great! Beer & cocktails cheap & bartenders nice. 2 hours, 4 bags of free popcorn & 3 bowls of pretzels later, we were in love with this place! The bathrooms are interesting...in the basement & scary- but what else would you expect from a dive bar? I highly recommend this place instead of a trendy, expensive place to share laughs & good times with friends.
author: Heather H.

description:
5 stars for my place. Really, it looks shady as hell from the outside, but this place KICKS ASS.

I'm not a smoker, but I could tolerate it here. It's divey, gritty, but homey in a weird way. Decor varied from Bob Marley to the Beatles, to of course, Chelsea FC stuff. Music varied from Warren G & Nate Dogg to Coldplay to Tears for Fears, and it was pretty loud. If that's not character, I don't know what is.

The bartenders were very friendly and adorable. Giving folks at the bar popcorn and pretzels, taking shots with patrons and giving out thirsty looking fellas shots of Jameson on the house. You could tell clearly who were regulars, but we were treated just as kindly.

-1 star for a prehistoric looking insect that crawled along the bar. Death by Heineken bottle.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
Came here in the midst of a twelve-day bar crawl (YTDDOC, holla!) and got exactly what I was expecting.

Chelsea Place is a dive bar on the grungy edge of Union Square, and I mean that in the best way possible. A family of Korean bartendresses? Check. Microwave popcorn (and I mean they will just nuke the bag and hand it to you)? Check. Cheap, stiff drinks? Check. Trash bins stored in the very back of the bar next to a lone table? Check. Credit cards accepted, with a $20 minimum, when the average drink is $5? Check!

Churchill it ain't, but this place is great in the way that only a thoroughly seedy bar can be. If you're in the neighborhood and need to kill an hour with some drinks (with or without friends), stop by.
author: Sam K.

description:
We came here because it was still afternoon and Tunnel Top wasn't open yet.   Why is it so hard to find a good, open bar before 5?

Our experience:
- confused drink orders
- a long, dark hair in one of the drinks.  Yes, it was then given to us free, but ewwwwwwww.
- a garbage can next to the table we were sitting--complete with smells.
-really strong drinks
-smoking is allowed (although it must be illegal)
- a dart board on the wall with no darts.
author: Katharine A.

description: Fun and divey, and if it's slow, you can challenge the bartender to a game of Liars Dice for a shot!
author: Bill B.

description:
Cheap drinks? Check. Hot Asian Chick Bartenders? Check. Awesome jukebox? Check. Interesting Patrons? Check. 

In other words, Chelsea Place has all the elements you need for a good time. What you do with any of the components is directly proportional to the amount of fun you will have here.
author: Lyn P.

description:
Friday I was hanging out with Ashley M and another yelper that's on here as Dupa B, I know his real name but for the sake of his anonymity I'll keep it to myself. Our first stop was Chelsea Place. It was an epic bar crawl night and I've decided to review every place we went in order.

I'd promised them a wild time here and for some reason it was quieter than I'd ever seen it, as Dupa said it might be because there was a big card game in the back. Either way now that I've been here a few times my impression of the place has changed a little. This place is full of interesting characters but they are also very friendly. This is the kind of place where you can strike up a conversation with a stranger and actually have an interesting talk. As someone that loves to talk to new people and hear their stories this is a great place to hang out. It's one of the few places I can go to alone with out any concern that I'll be bored.

This is one of those places where if you buy the bartenders one of those half shots of tequila or whiskey (lady drink) they'll hang around and talk to you for a few minutes. Some people call this kind of bar a "hostess bar" and while not an entirely accurate description it fits better than anything else.

Unfortunately they allow smoking but it's pretty well ventilated so unless you are sitting right next to someone with a cigarette it isn't too bad.
author: Manny F.

description: Good company & a rum & coke, too much fun!  We escaped the cold weather outside to get cozy inside. The juke box was cranking out some great tunes, which always makes everything better.
author: Winny S.

description: Love this place! Great service, cool crowd, true City bar. Tourists need not apply! I will have no problem going back again! The bartender were great, draft beers tasted great! Highly recommend it!
author: Kane S.

description:
A young college student knows how to save a dime or two and does so by visiting San Francisco by taking up a friend's offer of some free floor space in their small apartment. So on one of our last nights of our 5 day stay, all 3 of us visiting decided we needed a break and ended up walking aimlessly about the city at night and ended up at Chelsea's after a few dead ends at bars that close on Sunday, lame. 

Now this is a dive bar if I've ever seen one. Chairs and tables that were probably listed under the free section of Craigslist littered the small space and the dingy smell of old bar lingers in the air but hey for $9 you can get TWO decent sized mugs of Widmer Hefeweizen so I'll shut up and drink my beer. The Korean bartender was funny and kept me entertained with her stories of rebelling as an 11 year old drunk, showed me her tattoo, and discussion of the unfortunate genetic dispositions of most Asians in the chest area. Light, fun, and entertaining, Chelsea's is a good place to stop by for a beer or two.
author: Joyce K.

description:
Dive bars hit my sweet spot. 

This dive is great because everyone is always having a good time and there is never an uncomfortable moment, except maybe if you've had one to many and you're trying to make it down the tiny back staircase to the restroom, I'm surprised that I have yet to fall :)

I love the Chelsea bartendresses, so sweeet and I love that dice game! Even though they have to remind me how to play each time I go in, they never stop smiling. 

Lots of TV screens playing sports, well lots for a little bar, peanuts, jukebox, smoking inside... my only rant, well it's' not even a rant is that they have no pool table.

Cheers to next time~
author: Jaime H.

description: I'm giving this place 5 stars.  Not because of the service, the drinks, or the ambiance, no all of that is pretty below average actually.  But the bathroom is my favorite in the whole city.  You just have to check it out.  I won't bother saying anything else except GO HERE, and USE THE BATHROOM!
author: Kyle K.

description:
Only 15 reviews thus far? People scared of a neighborhood bar? Maybe they were intimidated by the Asian barkeep with the naturual platinum blonde hair? Or maybe it was the fumes coming out this place (people smoke here, okay by me)? Who knows?

All I know that this is my kind of bar. Came here after Bar Crudo and had a good time with an old friend. The girls behind the bar made sure the drinks were flowing (maybe they had more incentive after my friend opened up a tab) and everyone here seemed friendly enough.

It did seem like a labyrinth to get to the bathroom but I think that just added to the overall likability of this place.
author: Art O.

description:
'Collin is a one-pump chump,'  according to a scorned lover with a permanent pen.  Whoever this guy is, he must have been a REALLY big jerk for her to grab a marker from her purse and scribble this slur on the bathroom wall in her 8th grade-educated penmanship.

I'm guessing Collin doesn't come here anymore.  *pause*  Still, that doesn't stop my eyes from grazing over the regulars and wondering if one of them is the alleged minuteman.

In order to get to the bathroom to see what the ladies of Chelsea Place think about their conquests, you'll need to walk through the bar, wind down the stairs, skip through a hallway, beat down some more carpet, and face a very weird padded door.

I imagine the path is similar to one in an old speakeasy during prohibition.  But with invisible monsters and stuff.  It would make one hell of a Haunted House, that's for sure, so be careful. 

The drinks at this dark and dank dive bar are cheap and stiff, especially given the proximity to Union Square.

Not a party place, but a great spot to bring someone with whom you're having a clandestine affair, just make sure she doesn't excuse herself to the restroom with a Sharpie.
author: Janney B.

description:
I think the only reason that people come into this place is that the management turns a blind eye to the smokers.  Either that or they want to flirt with the bartenders.  (overheard quote bartender to patron: "Can you give me $2 to play some music?".... He came up with it.)  

I know folks want to call it a dive bar, but shouldn't a dive bar have a drink on the menu that costs less than $3.50? Isn't a cheap drunk the whole point of a dive?   

As for me, I forgot how much the smoke burns my eyes.  I think it's karma trying to tell me something.
author: dan d.

description:
Friday evening ...quiet , not crowded...attentive staff.
Nothing to complaint, nothing to get exited about.
Actually it was quiet enough to have a conversation with friends.
I need to comback ...
author: Dupa B.

description: Friendly staff, fun regulars, eclectic drop-ins.  Fun little space.  Oh, and smoking no longer allowed.
author: Mark D.

description:
Somewhere on the outskirts of the Financial District lies a bizarro parallel universe of a dive bar wrapped in a thick cloud of stale smoke, and staffed by what look like Korean hookers with fishnets.  In a good way.

It's definitely a no-nonsense kind of place when it comes to drinks, and this philosophy even extends to their stacking of napkins and cookware along the wall by where you're sitting.

It anything, it's worth venturing down the creaky staircase with psychedelic colored carpet down to the bathroom, which probably looks exactly the same as a century ago, and could have been stolen from the Shining mansion.
author: Eric C.

description:
I like it a lot!

Just decided to go check it out after reading all the reviews.  I made sure I knew what I was getting myself into.  It was hot in there no air-con on one of those its 90 degrees in SF days.   

I got the cold beer off tap.  It was good.  I stepped away from the bar and moved to the far wall because I knew that the ladies behind the bar tended to flirt.     I could feel it already.  So yeah if your single and have low self esteem then this place would probably pump it up a bit.  

When I was finished with one beer, one of them asked me for another pretty quickly.  So yeah got the 2nd beer, and now I'm slightly buzzed and writing this after arriving back to my hotel room. 

Its a divey atmosphere like everybody says.   It has 3 tvs going at it.  And the jukebox seemed to have good music.  

All in all. It was fun.   I went solo so if I can handle it anybody can.  This place doesn't have the regulars that stare you down.  If they are it's probably becuase they think one of the bargirls is their girlfriend.   And its definitely all bargirls. 

There is popcorn.  There is smoke.  

It just seems like a good place to chill out and grab a drink to relax after a long day.
author: Homer S.

description:
This bar was less than fifty feet from my apartment for a year so you can bet your ass i was here more than i should have been. 

Never in my life had i been exposed to a city dive bar but Chelsea Place left a good impression. Friends from my building and i would hit this place like twice a week after class, and always stop by to say hi to the owner Jen, once a weekend after a night of partying. 

The service is.. good. I am reluctant to say so because they Jen hires new bartenders frequently that have little or no experience. After a just a few weeks though, their knowledge expands and you get to know them very well, all very sweet ladies. 

The clientele are mostly regulars, all of which are nice people. I have encountered some assholes in the place which were dealt with if they were being too rowdy. 

I am not going to be a narc, but i would deduct a star for the lack of air quality on busy nights. Too bad i love the place as much as i do. Nothing could sway me from my five star review. NOTHING.

Memories from this place include a few birthdays, many stumbles back to my place, my longboard being ran over by a taxi, kim-chi noodles, liars die, meeting my first set of city friends and Roxanne by the Police.

cheers to jen, travis, tim, jackie, dan, jenny, and thai pete.  You guys are the sickness.
author: Peter T.

description: Went to SF with some friends on a week day and was in search of a place to get a drink. Went to Chelsea Place and yes it is a dive bar but in a good way. It's small but cozy and Michelle the bar tender was very nice. They have a great Juke box and the drinks were very reasonable. Fun place to kill some time waiting for the other bars in the area to open up.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Good service and not overly crowded. Great beer prices too! This was our last stop every night of our trip to San Francisco and not just because it was across the street from out hotel.
author: katie b.

description: Small, dark and friendly: a very good dive bar. Perfect for a beer to wet your whistle while trekking up Powell.
author: Chris L.

description: Beer was cold, cheap and the atmosphere was perfect for a night of drinking. Bar staff was friendly & did not skimp on the alcohol!
author: Ernest B.

description:
My favorite dive bar in San Fran!
Playing 1's and 6's for drinks is so fun!
author: D J.

description:
A blase two stars for this oddly-situated-on-Nob-Hill dive, only because it comes fairly close to that dive-bar aesthetic I'm endlessly searching for. It could stand to be a touch darker, but it certainly is dingy, small, and free of modern decorations (all highly desirable characteristics), with an odd mish-mash of wall adornments. Lady Pestlebottom and I sat at an old marble table which was awkwardly placed under a ledge along the back wall, which one could ineffectively hide one's head beneath, or rest one's head upon it after just the right number of cocktails. Upon said ledge were strewn orange crumbs from some cheese-based cracker snack. One aesthetic point.

The bartendresses were nice, and the patrons were of a mixed variety of white males. All were smoking. Three televisions broadcasted sporting events, always a sign of a boring drinking establishment.

Aesthetic points aside, we will most likely not visit this establishment again. I was quite turned off by the rampant cigarette smoking and extremely loud and irritating music. The sort of popular music the kids are listening to these days with the voice-modulated vocals that I can't stand. Although at one point the lights grew slightly dimmer and a Bon Jovi ballad was played. A slight improvement, but overall the ambience was not thrilling for us, and so we made a hasty exit as soon as our glasses were drained, and headed downhill in search of something darker...

(we did not find it that evening. See the Hi-Tide for our next disappointment.)
author: Mortimer P.

description: Cool local place with local people - If you are tired of the SF show off and need a break have a beer among nice locals!
author: Bertrand F.

description:
I can't tell if it was it the 50 year old Korean bartender lady in fishnets, or the giant marijuana plant skillfully-scrawled in chalk on the dart scoreboard, but something about this dark, catacomb-ey dive atop the Stockton Tunnel made me smile.  I stopped to get some treatment for my HypoMakersMarkEmia (it's vanishingly rare but crippling) after some Union Square sale rack-hopping.  As I crunched on free peanuts in front of the long-unused fireplace, my eyes wandered from all the old client photos on the wall to the mix of tchotchkes above the bar from various decades, and I felt at home.  Except for the creepy Asian "good luck" cat statuette that I have a phobia for.  It just WAVES at you all night.  
Anyway, Chelsea Place is a rich old stinky neighborhood dive that I'd recommend any time of day.
author: Eric S.

description: divey bar, cute girls, low priced drinks. great formula to success. the girls will play dice with you, keep a great conversation and the owner has a great personality to boot. baaaaaam 4 stars in my book.
author: Q L.

description:
This is a really wierd place.  Brown water leaked from the ceiling... and it wasn't raining.  The korean ladies were down right mean, when I tried to order a shot, I heard "why don't you shut up and finish your beer (thats her in the picture)."  The bathroom is a converted bomb shelter.  The locals inside are reasons to go to AA.  The jukebox is a joke.

That said, I had a blast, even when they kicked us out.  The refrain was ",get the f### out, get the f### out, get the f### out."  It has nothing on New Orleans dives, but it is a worthy spot for those seeking  authentic absurdity, flavored with good old fashioned bi-polarity.
author: Cavan P.

description:
All right, I know this is supposed to be a charming dive bar, but for some reason, this place just creeped me out. Maybe it was the seemingly drunk older gentlemen next to me at the bar, who, it turns out, were drinking O'doul's, which didn't make any sense to me, but I guess perhaps they had tied on a good one early and wanted to stay out. Maybe it was the (bless them, they are very sweet, but...) barmaids. They were amiable, but something seemed so hostess bar-esque about them. And the guys trying to dominate the attention of them seemed more like the over-eager patrons of the lady bars in Thailand, rather than a dive bar in Nob Hill. 

This place smells bad, too. 

Unless I move into an apartment across the street, there doesn't seem to be much of a chance of me going back to this little hole.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Why does this place average a generous 4 stars?

This place is terrible. Its an old run down hole in the wall bar next to Chinatown. Place is dirty, I was hesitant to drink out of their glasses. Bartenders are shaddy and pretty skanky. I wouldn't be suprised if this was a front for a secret brothel. Avoid at all costs. I rather get my drink on at a 7-11.
author: David W.

description:
I remember going to Chelea Place like 5 times. Never remember leaving. I do, however, remember a bunch of girls kissing, almost getting into 2 fights with a couple different people, hot bartenders, cheap drinks and ending up in a fountain somewhere. I swear, I'm never drinking again.

Good times.
author: Philly D.

description:
Dim lighting, generic decor, and a hideously slow-and-grinding Black Sabbath tune warbling from the jukebox gave me a bad impression of Chelsea Place right from the get-go.  It's got the rustic dive bar feel, but it's sense of the rustic derives not from  quality trappings that are broken in, but from cheap props that have long since worn out.  The ceiling with it's sizable cross-beams and yellowing plaster has a look of antiquity about it, but from there on down the entire place is sided with fake walnut paneling with vertical stripes of simulated wood.  Decor is little more than stock posters, neon, and mirrors from beer suppliers, while a lone banner of some sort from Chelsea is the only unique item gracing the walls.

A small back area that looks like it housed a pool table at one time hosts several isolated cocktail tables.  A gas fireplace is nearby, though it wasn't fired up during my last visit. The on-tap beer assortment wasn't all that great, and the liquor selection was on par with that of a down-and-outers bar in the Tenderloin.

Chelsea's crowd was a varying mix of seasoned regulars and passers-through from the Union Square area.  The mix is about fifty-fifty during the day, but the regulars rule the roost come nightfall.  It had the feel of a place that many visit, but few call home.  The crowd seemed friendly, but I didn't get a chance to chat with anyone due to the fact that two more snarling Black Sabbath tunes came from the jukebox, which then launched into a gruesome barrage of "classic rock".  AC-DC's "Highway to Hell" signaled an upcoming medley of similar tunes, and the bottom of my glass left me little reason to stick around.

Gritty. Grimy. No sense of history, no unique charm, and NO SOUL.  A feeble attempt at old-world ambiance that's cheaply done and long since worn out.  A gag-provoking jukebox, garden-variety patrons, and the absence of on-theme decoration create an environment that's little more than a dark hole to drink in.  My last visit was the third chance I'd given this place in two years.  Strike one, strike two, SteeeeeRIKE THREE!!! Yer out....
author: Mike W.

description:
Best dive bar.  Ever.

A recent transplant to the neighborhood, my first and only introduction to Chelsea Place had been hearing the ruckus outside of the bar that generally begins around 11:30pm and sometime doesn't stop until close to 3am. It seemed that something in their drinks  causes their customers to suffer from Voice Immodulation Syndrome; luckily, I have dual paned windows, and frankly all the noise only piqued my curiosity.   

When I finally moseyed on over, I was pleasantly surprised by my experience.  The bar had quite a variety of patrons, including a wedding party still in their wedding regalia ordering pizza to the dark back section.  The bar tenders are delightfully snarky and know how to have a good time- including playing 1's and 6's with you to test your luck at a free drink (or buying them a shot).   Plus, they offer free peanuts and popcorn when you need a little something to soak up the juice, though quite honestly I would have much rather had the king crab leg that one of the bar tenders was voraciously gnawing on behind the bar.  Further, the bar offers a pre-January 1st 1995 experience as mentioned in other reviews.  Not that this actually applies to me, but something about it makes it all the smuttier- and I like smutty.  

To complete this short and sweet review, I affirm all of my supporting points to my thesis sentence are true.  (Did that work?) Finally, in closing, I compel you fine readers of Yelp to give Chelsea Place and it's bartenders your hard earned money.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This place is AWESOME!!

Me and my friend CHELSEA decided to go to this place after we found that Voda Vodka was closed down. We are definitely happy we came here.

The bartenders are awesome and they offered us free popcorn and pretzels. The drinks were nice and strong but not too strong.. average drink prices for SF. Parking not too hard to find. 2 TVs on the wall and smoker friendly. Would definitely come here again!
author: Dan M.

description: My whole life I've fantasized of being a recognized and welcomed bar patron like on Cheers ... a "regular" who has "my usual."  I think I may finally be living the dream ... or maybe I grew up watching too much TV.
author: Rosie M.

description:
Fernet is chilled.  Very tasty chilled (or at room temperature, but variety is good.)

Is this a Chelsea football club bar?
author: Wakako U.

description: Went here 2-7-11 evening, I met a friend at ez5 last friday and called me about 7:30pm if I wanted to get some drinks, I thought alright.  It's not bad, he appears to know some regular patrons that frequent this bar.  Beer is $4 for heinenken and miller(again not bad), and they had some menus which allowed us to order food from other eateries/into this establishment.  The female bartenders are cool,my friend likes joke around with her.  I met some of these regulars, and seem to be good folks.  I might  visit this bar again another time.  Parking wasn't bad, I guess it's monday and in the evening.
author: Jer W.

description:
The other posts sum it up pretty nicely. 
The smell was off-putting. Bartenders were heavy-handed and condescending in a good way. Crowd was a little rowdy, a little un-hinged. One particularly drunk patron who stumbled about and shouted a string of obscenities at everyone in her immediate vicinity turned out to be one of the owners. 
I must have looked like a long-lost regular customer, because a number of people approached me and welcomed me back with hugs and drink offers. They all called me Barry (Benny? I don't remember - either way, it wasn't my name). 
There's a citation from the SF county health dept. for failing to comply with the no-smoking ordinance, framed and proudly displayed on the wall. Everyone (but me) was smoking, using ashtrays McGyver-ed out of coasters. 
Collin Davies is, apparently, still a one-pump chump.
author: stephen a.

description:
Chelsea'a Place...
If your into a great dive bar with crazy people, and hot Koreans this is your bar. Just remember that there are 20+ year regulars there, so mind your manners.
author: Enoch K.

description:
This place is seriously cool. Its not fancy or spectacular but it packs some fun. The bartenders, a group of Asian ladies, are all outgoing and outspoken,creating an entertaining and interactive environment. Everyone seems to be having a great time at what would just be normally another filthy bar on the streets.

Drinks are pretty cheap but the ladies are not exactly the best at making drinks so selection may be limited. Great place to stop by before a crazy night out. This is one bar in which I enjoy the lack of aesthetics.
author: Ed L.

description:
So my friend was hiding from someone, and we were on a bender for the same reason,  she had to flee a hotel bar - it was very "on the lam"-- and we figured the maybe the Tunnel Top would be good, it's dark and has a balcony.  

Tunnel Top was closed, Chelsea Place was not, we went in, we drank drinks.  It was a better time than we'd have had at the Tunnel Top anyway.  The decor is rough and the layout confusing (bathroom is lost somewhere downstairs), but the patrons are damn friendly and so was the bartender.  She ultimately invited us to her show that night, she was backing up SF's best Japanese singing cowboy at a favorite bar/club of mine the Mission. 

The juke box was solid, if not exactly/always my thing and they gave out bar snacks of some kind.  I have been here several times now and really it's a nice bar, divey and local but nice.  Only drawback is the enormous TVs everywhere - which is bad for me, because as a long time non-TV owner, even car ads can mesmerize me.   I have seen none of the dubious interactions and suggestions of immorality others mention, just local patrons and a longtime staff.
author: Gustie L.

description:
Chelsea Place definitely gets better the more you drink.  I think it reaches its prime rating somewhere between beer #3 and scotch #2.  

That might only mean something to the people that know me.  

Okay, well then, it's a good spot to pass some boozey hours.  And Chelsea Place improves upon further inspection.
author: Tamar N.

description: Who doesn't like to see under age drinking and the occasional patron smoking in a bar? Not me. Think about the cheesiest bar in Tahoe, multiply it by 1,000 and you have it, Chelsea Place. I know what you are thinking, this sounds like it sucks but not advocating under age drinking, but, this place is not that bad. The bar smells like an old ash tray. The decor reminds me of an old 70's nightmare. The clientele...wow...the clientele. I don't want to sound like I am "All" that but some of the people got hit, no I take that back, beaten, chocked, resuscitated, brought back to life then beaten by an ugly stick over and over again. Other than that, the place is pretty cool. You get what you pay for. Check it out someday.
author: Edson C.

description:
It was my friend's B-Day, the Sunday before Prez's Day.  But the effing losers at Top of the Mark had closed before midnight, and the douchbags at Tonga Room stopped serving alcohol.  Where to go, being mindful of the ladies' "shoe issues"?

We walked down three steep city blocks, finally stumbling into Chelsea Place.  I had a bit of an uneasy feeling that accompanies marching into a random unknown seedy dive bar.  But that was immediately washed away by thick cigarette smoke and a really friendly bartender.  So friendly that she gave my friend a complimentary birthday "blowjob."  The fun continued when we were  poured three shots of Jagermeister, and warned that although one was cold, the other two were warm.  To add to the coolness of it all, we bummed a smoke a passed it around like a joint.  Good jukebox...competitive arm wrestling on the flat screen...great  times.
author: Leon R.

description:
This  is the sketchiest bar I have _ever_ been to in San Francisco, and I loved every minute of it. 

You couldn't create a shadier environment if you tried. And it's $&@# awesome.
author: Joe K.

description: A dive bar I wish I didn't dive into! Drinks were served in small juice glass' with lots of ice and little booze. It was also expensive! Restroom was dirty. I was visiting from Los Angeles and have been to many dive bars and this was the worst dive bar I've been to. Go down the block a little more and go to Tunnel Top Bar!
author: Ken V.

description:
It's a Dive! Just so you know what you are getting yourself into this is a typical dive bar. Long single bar, missed-matched wall hangings that build character, retro jukebox and a few small tables. 

Once inside you will be greeted by the lovely female bartenders who will gladly dance on the bar with you and serve you up delicous, pipping hot pop-corn (free of course). No worries if the music runs dry because the bartenders will happily give some change to livin-up the mood. 

And here's the best part, the insider tip...if you are feeling lucky that is. Go ahead and try your luck against the bartenders at their version of dice. You win = free shot, You lose= you buy them one and take a shot together. 

No fancy amenities. Just good old-time fun with tunes, pop-corn and friendly bartenders.
author: Theresa T.

description:
So I decided to take Bart to work and I got off at the Powell station. I haven't trekked this part of the city in years. So I'm sipping on wild turkey as I walked through the area. I decided to grab a beer at the liquor store on Stockton right before the tunnel towards Chinatown. It's thanksgiving so it closed early. I was determined to find a store and have a beer before work. I walked back and trekked up Powell made a right on bush. Located a store half a block down the street. Closed dangit!! So I walk back up bush saw Chelsea Place on the left. I've passed by this place plenty of times years ago. There was a guy smoking outside and we chatted a bit. I told him my quick story how I  ended up there. So why don't you come in and have drink. I thought hell why not, I've walked this far. Pretty much an old school dive nothing fancy. I looked in and saw
Asian ladies bartending. Not a whole lot of selection of beers, but that's ok. I was welcomed by the regulars. Some people may be intimidated by dives as I have read here , but I'll go
Anywhere to try it out. Bottom line I had 2 sierras 9 bucks free snacks and you can smoke inside. I quit smoking, but it didn't bother me. I left walked to work and enjoyed the night. I will be coming back!!!
author: Oliver M.

description: The woman working was terribly rude and disrespectful. I entered and sat down 'fore i had moments between responsibilities and within minutes she moved to offer me a drink. When I asked for water, because I needed to hydrate before drinking more (i am two drinks in before the end of happy hour) she said I was not allowed to sit there unless I spent money/order a soda (I don't drink sugar). And when I stated I was to order a drink after some water she began THREATENING me she'd call the police. The discourse continued for moments, myself high lighting her severe lack of respect and urging her to waste her time on cops for the hilarity or calm down because that is not appropriate behavior. Other patrons were forced to suffer the uncomfortable banter (and her presence for the duration of their evening) instead of my delightful company- which is more suited to ANYWHERE ELSE, apparently. I understood her need to acquire money to replace mutual human respect but she straight sucks. Her trite bartender humor was not even well received by dudes drinking patron. ZERO STARS
author: Denise C.

description: Meh. No drink specials on a Thurs before 7pm, pretty light crowd, didn't really feel it. Should have gone to the Tunnel Top.
author: Destiny A.

description:
Yes, it's a dive so I guess dive standards are in order.  If you want to show off the fancy schmancy collared dress shirt you just overpaid for in order to spend too much money on lousy drinks and impress the ladies with the cool credit card you're financing with what remains of your graduate school loans, do not come here.  Believe me, there are better places in SF to show off your bling and your bad boy self.

If you have a more simple approach to life:  Drink alcohol, Scream loudly, Have fun,  Fall down,  Stand up,  Have more fun.  Chelsea is a good place.  Ah.  Simplicity...
author: Aron L.

description:
It is a dive, but a very nice one as far as dive bars go.  The standout attractions for me are the 1.) Darts and 2.) The friendly, attractive bar maids.  I used to live in Saigon, (HCMC) Vietnam and have really missed the bar atmosphere there which is very much like Cheers where you know everyone and the service extremely friendly.  I found that this place matches up very closely to what you will find in SE Asia.  

As for the darts, I used to be a darts team captain in the Saigon league but did not want to travel all the way out to Eagles Drift in the Sunset District to throw a few.  Chealsea place is right down the street from me and very easy to pop in and get some practice in around 6pm before it gets crowded.  I've learned that Chelasea Place might also participate in the league starting in February if there is enough interest which I hope will happen.  If anyone is into darts let me know and we'll do a game of 501 now and then.  I think I'll be going to this place Friday and Saturday evenings much more frequently.  

Finally, the "Boom Boom Room" is not for boom boom but for darts and only opened up for tournaments.  ;)
author: Mateo D.

description:
I like dive bars, and this one is near my place, it's cheap, they have multiple TVs, and they offer peanuts in the shell as a snack.  Bartenders are friendly, and on a good night one of them will walk around playing the violin.

I wish they had a pool table (that is, if they had the room) and I don't like going home smelling like smoke.
author: Joseph N.

description:
I was drawn to this bar because my name is Chelsea, and was delightfully surprised to find good prices on booze and that I could smoke inside. Awesome. I'm also proud to say that "my" place has some hot lady bartenders! 

Cheers to Chelsea Place!
author: Chelsea H.

description: According to one of the people I went with, they said this is the place to go to get the bartenders to hit on you to feel better about yourself.  They are very friendly here.  Again, there's not a whole lot a room here but if you go on a Saturday night, you can find a place to sit.  Definitely a neat little change from the crowded bars in the Mission.
author: Amy J.

description: As dive bars go this one's pretty good. The cute bartenders are friendly. The beer is cold and the jukebox has good tunes. Beware the dice game. I don't know if it's rigged, but it makes my spidey sense tingle.
author: Chad P.

description: Imagine walking in to your living room to see i't s been transformed in to a mini bar with about 8 30-somethings sitting around smoking cigarettes, playing dice with the hot Asian bartenders while taking down shots of whiskey. That's pretty much how I felt when I walked in to Chelsea. It's cozy to say the least and while it wreaks of cigarettes and stale beer there's something quite alluring about this place. They've got all the primary ingredients for a true dive bar...and I love them for that. You can go in for some pop corn and a beer in a relaxed and chill atmosphere all the while being served by a cute bartender.
author: Kristy M.

description:
Gimmick of all attractive female bartenders to attract male clientele. But not many regulars the night I went. The patrons were vacationers from the nearby hotels looking for a drink.

Bathrooms are scary (dark alley scary).
Non-smokers beware because this place has more smokers than a chimney (even though there are no smoking signs posted).

The dingiest dive bar I have ever seen.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Ended up here late last night with the workmates, and I gotta say it's pretty charming for such a dive.  I think it gets an extra star for being so easy compared to Le Colonial, where we came from.  The bartendresses  were attentive and mildly amusing.  They got a little insistent after last call but I will forgive them that.

I can't exactly imaging seeking this place out, but if you're in the neighborhood and looking for a spot to get your drink on, give it a go.  I'd probably leave the date at home, though.
author: Oliver N.

description:
This was the first bar I ventured into after officially moving in; nice bartenders, free popcorn, giant TV, smoke if you want (but not legal), and plenty of dice for that funny game I learned how to play living in China. 

The bathroom is downstairs and most of the customers are cool. I met a Korean journalist who invited me over for a Korean Christmas.  Its an unassuming neighborhood bar about 15 ft from my front door; no complaints. 

Also, one of the bartenders has a violin that she can play along with the jukebox -- way cool. The $20 min on credit cards sucks, but they have been flexible with me about it.
author: Dylan ..

description:
Back in the 90's a few friends and I found this place on a night roaming the city looking for drinks.  We had a great time at this place partially because of the charm, partially because of the patrons, but mostly from the bathroom.  Get your mind out of the gutter...  The bathroom at this venerable location is located down this flight of stairs somewhere just above Hades.  You remember the worst bathroom ever from Train Spotting?  When you're a bit tipsy, the staircase seems a lot longer.  It was spooky and we got a kick out of it.

Well fast forward a decade or so and once again while wandering around the city I stumble upon a familiar sign for Chelsea Place.  I'm in.  Looks about the same and the place is packed.  Is this the neighborhood haunt?  There were a bunch of guys there for the free sandwich fixins that the bartender put out.  Everyone was friendly.  I love places like this.  And the bathroom is as I remembered it...down the stairs...deep underground...  Cool.
author: Eric W.

description: Great Bar, good location. Kind of like a SF version of Cheers. Barmaids are always cute and 420 friendly. However, the place could use a good cleaning.
author: Brad J.

description:
When you want divey-DIVEY, this is the place to be...just don't be too drunk to stumble off the steps going to the bathroom.

I like my drinks strong and served with an attitude and the bartenders there do just that. I've been here on many random nights and they just continue on with my random adventure of a night. I knew I was in trouble when "ONE BOURBON, ONE SCOTCH, ONE BEER" was playing when I got in. Seriously...
author: Rachel C.

description: I'm pretty sure this bar is what dive bar means. In the time it took to get one drink I stunk of cigarettes on the way out. Dimly lit, drunks screaming, barely any seats that aren't at the bar. This seems like the perfect place to go on a pretty serious bender.
author: Nick W.

description:
I dimly remember having been here before, but I must not have been in the right mood.

Well, last night was the end of a long, hardworking weekend and the right time for a no-nonsense dive for liquor and beer with my compatriots.

And I must say - me likes!
Yes it's dodgy and smelly, very generic and there was the guy who ended up throwing shot glasses at the wall because he'd discovered his own mortality and couldn't come to grips with the fact that "I'm gonna die. You're gonna die. We're all gonna fucking die".

But, on the other hand the bathroom was almost clean, the drinks were cheap, free peanuts aplenty and the barkeep Jennifer was really nice and cool. And man, could she hold her liquor!

Four happy, hungover stars!
author: Tatjana G.

description:
A dive decorated in CFC memorabilia?!?! HELL YES! 

One of the guys in my IPRC class found this place for us to drink after our exam - we were all stressed from the exam and needed several stiff drinks so this place was a good call! 

The bar is definitely a dive, and cleanliness of the drinking glasses was questionable, but if you're looking to pound a few, who cares? haha, ok, you should still care. 

Our bartender was very nice (we never saw the bottom of our glasses), there were free pretzels/peanuts, and the bar has CFC memorabilia!
author: Rosa S.

description: Great, friendly neighborhood bar that hasn't changed in the ten years I've been coming here.  Good juke box (older Stones, Roxy Music, Buddy Guy, etc...).  Lots of regulars but it gets crowded and a little douchie when the Tunnel Top overflow squeezes in but fortunately they don't tend to linger.
author: Dan L.

description:
Don't go here. If you're reading about this place on Yelp you're far too trendy and cool to be hanging out here. At least you probably think you are.

I've lived around the corner from this place for 4 years and didn't go in until about a month ago. It always had the look of a total derelict dive bar and the type of place where as soon as you walk in everyone would stare you down until you left. It's not, it's a blast except for the fact that everyone smokes. The staff are awesome if a little gruff at times, the drinks are affordable for the location and the environment is just nice.

So if you're here looking for the next good spot to destroy by making it ultra popular, don't go to Chelsea place.
author: N S.

description: Love this place. Generally roll here after Summer Place to really get the night going. Love the always friendly (and usually really hot Asian) bartenders who can all seriously put back some tequila when they play liar's dice with you. Always something interesting to see or people to talk to.
author: Lloyd B.

description: I love this place, plain and simple. The liquor is expensive but the beers are fine, just fine. Go here. It's like the Cheers of Nob Hill...only all the bartenders are Asian ladies.
author: Lauren C.

description: Its a great old dive bar close to work. Very San Francisco with plenty of bar stool seating. Its a little smelly but not as dim and trendy as the Tunnel Top down the block. They loose a star for long range restrooms.
author: Melissa B.

description: After initial hesitation about going into this smoke-filled den of iniquity, I ended up having an awesome time. The charismatic and hilarious cute Asian bartenders are a lot of fun to watch preform. They use crass language and rib customers -- it's very entertaining. The service was good too, since they were practically pouring the liquor down our throats. Peer pressure much? Haha. Chelsea's is a great dive bar experience.
author: Marisa S.

description: parkiing is difficult to access this "dive" bar. nice drink selection and a clientele different from other dive bars. normal people who aren't asian. there tv's on here.
author: Victor G.

description:
Yes! Yes! Yes!  
     I rolled dice for my drinks and it was as awesome as it sounds!  
Soon after entering I saw a guy (Mike) rolling dice with one of the bartenders.  After a quick lesson I was ready.  For those of you that don't know the rules of "6 and 1" it works like this...
     Both you and the bartender get five dice.  The objective is to get rid of all your dice, you either do this by rolling a "6", in which case you pass it to your opponent who has to roll it next turn, or you roll a "1", in which case you put it aside and it is out of play.  You roll at the same time over and over until one of you emerges as the victor.  If you win you get a free drink of your choice and if you lose you have to buy the bartender a drink of her choice ($10 price cap).  This is a win win situation really because either way people are getting drunk.
     After 4 games...maybe 5, I either broke even or was one up, it gets fuzzy towards the end.
     I had a great time and will definitely be back! Thanks to Mike for teaching me the game!
author: Andrew R.

description: I'm a dive bar girl at heart and boy is this a dive bar. It's just a straight up bar, big wooden bar, some seats and a few TVs. That's it. Love it.
author: Cathy T.

description:
great relaxed atmosphere with amiable bartenders makes this bar a new standby.  nothing special inside (read dive), but definitely comfortable and not too crowded even on a friday night.  complimentary goldfish (nabisco, not sushi) at the bar are a definite plus.  

a great place to go and practice your liar's and then challenge the ladies behind the bar.  be prepared for some good-natured trash talking followed by getting your ass whooped and finished off by you buying your opponent a $9 shot of patron....of course....but i'll be back...oh yes...i will be back...
author: eric g.

description: Best divebar in the coutry - make sure you ask Dede to play dice with you!
author: Saman S.

description: This place is just F-U-N!! A great spot to meet continental and intercontinental travelers. I'm in my early 20s and I was by far the youngest there when I went, but it didn't seem to matter cause everyone was just enjoying themselves and not into "appearances," not that there is anything wrong with those kind of bars, but this place is a great vacation from that.
author: T W.

description: What to say? Not much. Like many others Duffman wandered in here because Tunnel Top was not open. Duffman was quite pleased. The drinks and prices are fine, cute bartender, friendly scene, a nice tv to watch the game, smoking allowed. Overall it was a great visit and Duffman can't say a bad thing about the place. However, it is what it is, and that is a good place but nothing special. 4 stars from Duffman. Wait, 5 stars from Duffman. Why? Please make your way to the bathroom.
author: Duffman D.

description: Good dive bar to stop by if you're in the 'hood. Would give 3.5 stars - it would be 4 if the prices actually reflected the divey atmostphere. $5 for a house vodka soda is reasonable but higher than I'd like for happy hour @ a dive. Bonus points for the free peanuts in shell they give you, and friendly Korean lady bartender - she seemed pretty toasted already at 4:30 as she appeared to be doing bourbon shots with the all male patrons seated @ the bar :p
author: Sherry K.

description: overpriced, sneaky bartenders take advantage of customers. lots of cigarette smoke!!!stay away!!!!!! minus one star. shitty bar!
author: Leeshawn N.

description: Walking into this place at 1pm on a tuesday afternoon I had no idea what to expect. There was an older gentlemen at the end of the bar and me. The bartender was playing the violin and the soda on tap guy was fixing the lines behind the bar. The music from the violin was a very nice addition to the ambiance. Chelsea place looked clean from what I saw and I plan on going back if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: D J.

description: This place is rad.  Came here on St. Patty's day due to the overflowing of drunkards at the Irish Bank.
